ATOM.definition: The smallest unit of ordinary matter that forms a chemical element, consisting of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
examples: An atom consists of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
Water molecules are made of hydrogen and oxygen atoms.

CELL.definition: The smallest structural and functional unit of an organism, typically microscopic and consisting of cytoplasm enclosed within a membrane.
examples: The human body contains trillions of cells.
Plant cells have a rigid cell wall.

GENE.definition: A unit of heredity which is transferred from a parent to offspring and determines some characteristic of the offspring.
examples: Eye color is determined by genes.
Scientists study genes to understand hereditary diseases.
GENE.etymology: From German 'Gen', from Greek 'genesis' meaning origin

WAVE.definition: A periodic disturbance of particles of a substance which may be propagated without net movement of the particles.
examples: Sound travels as a wave through the air.
Light waves can be reflected and refracted.
WAVE.etymology: From Old English 'wafian' meaning to wave with the hands

MASS.definition: A measure of the amount of matter in an object, typically expressed in grams or kilograms.
examples: The mass of an object determines its inertia.
Mass is different from weight.
MASS.etymology: From Latin 'massa' meaning lump or dough

BOND.definition: A force or mechanism that holds atoms together in a molecule or crystal.
examples: Covalent bonds share electrons between atoms.
Ionic bonds form between oppositely charged ions.
BOND.etymology: From Old Norse 'band' meaning something that binds

HEAT.definition: The transfer of energy from one body to another due to a difference in temperature.
examples: Heat flows from hot objects to cold ones.
Friction generates heat.

LENS.definition: A piece of transparent material with curved sides for concentrating or dispersing light rays.
examples: A magnifying glass uses a convex lens.
The lens of the eye focuses light on the retina.
LENS.etymology: From Latin 'lens' meaning lentil (due to its shape)

STEM.definition: The main body or stalk of a plant, which supports leaves, flowers, and fruits.
examples: The stem transports water from roots to leaves.
Some stems are modified to store food.

ROOT.definition: The part of a plant which attaches it to the ground and conveys water and nourishment from the soil.
examples: Roots anchor plants in the soil.
Carrots are edible roots.
ROOT.etymology: From Old English 'rot' meaning underground part

CORE.definition: The central or most important part of something, especially the innermost part of the Earth.
examples: The Earth's core is extremely hot.
The core of the Sun produces energy through fusion.

VOLT.definition: The SI unit of electromotive force, the difference of potential that would drive one ampere of current against one ohm resistance.
examples: A typical household outlet provides 120 volts.
Batteries are rated in volts.
VOLT.etymology: Named after Italian physicist Alessandro Volta

WATT.definition: The SI unit of power, equivalent to one joule per second, corresponding to the rate of consumption of energy.
examples: A 60-watt light bulb uses 60 joules of energy per second.
Power consumption is measured in watts.
WATT.etymology: Named after Scottish engineer James Watt

ACID.definition: A chemical substance that neutralizes alkalis, dissolves some metals, and turns litmus red; has a pH less than 7.
examples: Citric acid gives lemons their sour taste.
Strong acids can be corrosive and dangerous.

BASE.definition: A substance capable of reacting with an acid to form a salt and water, or accepting hydrogen ions; has a pH greater than 7.
examples: Sodium hydroxide is a common base.
Bases feel slippery to the touch.

SALT.definition: A chemical compound formed from the reaction of an acid with a base, with all or part of the hydrogen of the acid replaced by a metal.
examples: Table salt is sodium chloride.
Salts are ionic compounds.

WORK.definition: In physics, the transfer of energy to or from an object by means of a force acting on the object.
examples: Work is calculated as force times distance.
Lifting a weight requires work against gravity.
WORK.etymology: From Old English 'weorc' meaning action, deed

SPIN.definition: The intrinsic angular momentum of a subatomic particle, or rotation around an axis.
examples: Electrons have a property called spin.
The Earth spins on its axis.
SPIN.etymology: From Old English 'spinnan' meaning draw out and twist

IRON.definition: A strong, hard magnetic silvery-gray metal, the chemical element of atomic number 26.
examples: Iron is used to make steel.
Hemoglobin contains iron atoms.
IRON.etymology: From Old English 'iren', of Germanic origin

LEAD.definition: A soft, heavy, ductile bluish-gray metal, the chemical element of atomic number 82.
examples: Lead was once used in paint and gasoline.
Lead is toxic to humans.
LEAD.etymology: From Old English 'lead', of Germanic origin
